awd_titl_txt: Integrating Science with Mathematics and Engineering: Linking Home and School Learning for All Young Learners
awd_abstract_narration:
Children in preschool programs have few opportunities to engage meaningfully in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) disciplines. This is especially true in programs serving children from low-income communities, where resources are scarce. This study will investigate the integration of science with mathematics and engineering and develop resources that provide preschool children with integrated STEM learning experiences. The study will also investigate the connection between home and school learning and will develop resources that strengthen children's experiences at school and home. This will include investigating the needs of and designing for dual language learners who represent a large (and growing) proportion of the population served in public preschool programs. This project is funded by the Discovery Research preK-12 program (DRK-12), which seeks to significantly enhance the learning and teaching of STEM by preK-12 students and teachers, through research and development of innovative resources, models and tools. Projects in the DRK-12 program build on fundamental research in STEM education and prior research and development efforts that provide theoretical and empirical justification for proposed projects. 

Using design based research (DBR), the researchers will: (1) Develop learning blueprints to guide the design of classroom and family learning resources. (2) Co-design resources with teachers and parents from low-income as well as culturally and linguistically diverse communities. (3) Conduct a series of formative pilot studies with partner teachers and parents. (4) Conduct a quasi-experimental field study in preschool classrooms and homes to examine both implementation and learning outcomes. Data sources will include observations in classrooms and homes, surveys and interviews with teachers and parents, and child learning assessments. Analysis will include qualitative approaches to examine patterns of interaction and engagement with resources in classrooms and homes, as well as quantitative approaches to examine children's learning accounting for the multilevel structure of the data. The project involves a collaboration between Digital Promise Global, Education Development Center, WGBH and multiple early childhood programs in California and New York. A total of 28 preschool centers, 56 classroom teachers, 208 families and 560 children are expected to participate. Results from this project are intended to inform understanding of how young children learn STEM, how adults at school and home can support children's early STEM learning, and what supports are useful to diverse learners specifically. Results could also highlight design principles that can inform future early STEM education research and development efforts integrating media and technology.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Integrating Science, Mathematics and Engineering: Linking Home and School Learning for Young Learners

There is growing recognition of the importance and need for high-quality early science teaching and learning. The increased emphasis on early science stems from the recognition that: (1) young children are naturally interested in making sense of the world around them (Larimore, 2020), (2) early science experiences not only support children’s later science learning, but also promote and strengthen young children’s learning in other key areas (Bustamante et al., 2018; Clements et al., 2017; Conezio & French, 2002; Wheatley et al., 2016), and (3) young children have the right to learn about science phenomena and develop problem solving skills that will allow them to be problem solvers and active citizens in their communities (NASEM, 2022). 

Although science is increasingly recognized as a key dimension of early learning, young children, especially those in programs serving historically excluded communities, continue to have few opportunities to engage in high quality science activities (Dominguez & Stephens, 2022; Morgan et al., 2016). Research aiming to uncover factors that contribute to the lack of science education in early childhood classrooms suggest that preschool teachers may not devote as much instructional time to science due to a variety of reasons including low self-efficacy, limited knowledge about science instructional practices and lack of curricular materials to support young children’s science learning (Gerde et al. 2018; Maier, Bulotsky-Shearer, & Greenfield, 2013; Oppermann et al. 2019). While these studies contribute to our understanding of potential factors that contribute to the lack of high-quality science learning experiences available to preschool children, they sometimes present a deficit view of preschool educators as ill equipped to support their young learners as scientists. More recent work, however, suggests that preschool teachers do in fact view science as beneficial for young children and are interested and eager to be supported in their efforts to promote STEM learning (Pendergast, Lieberman-Betz, & Vail, 2017). 

Our work aimed to address this need, in partnership with preschool educators, families of young children and designers of curricula and media. Through an inclusive and collaborative process that centered the experiences and interests of children and families, the team co-designed and evaluated a science program that promotes early science learning through playful learning experiences; connects home and school learning; links science with engineering and math, strengthening children’s opportunity to meaningfully learn across domains; and leverages digital tools with unique affordances for STEM learning to strengthen (not replace) hands-on exploration.

The resulting program, Early Science with Nico & NorⓇ, is now freely available via WGBH’s First8Studios website (apps are also freely available via the Apple store). It includes: 

  • A Teacher Guide with sample, modifiable activities/lessons across three units (Plants, Ramps and Shadows), along with educative support for educators’ implementation. Activities match common preschool formats (circle time, small group activity and learning center ideas) and aim to promote science, math & engineering in meaningful and playful ways. 

  • A Family Guide with sample brief activities to inspire families to engage in science, math & engineering in playful ways, along with user-friendly material to help parents and caregivers feel prepared to engage in rich conversations with their children. 

  • 3 digital science journals to support engagement in science practices (observation, data collection, analysis and reflection) during collaborative science investigations. 

  • 8 Digital Games to strengthen children’s hands-on learning by providing opportunities to observe and explore science phenomena through simulations and easily test solutions. 

The project included three phases: (1) a co-design phase that involved building relationships and brainstorming ideas for science learning experiences, (2) a series of rapid user and pilot studies to test emerging activities in context (in classrooms along with teacher partners and in homes along with family partners) and inform iterations/refinements and (3) a field study to examine implementation in a new sample of classrooms and homes.  

Findings from the field study indicate that public preschool teachers successfully integrated science instruction into their classroom practice and appreciated the flexibility to modify, adapt or extend activities in ways that reflected their classroom context best. Similarly, findings indicate that families used the digital Family Guide to engage in activities, often adapting them to best reflect their home routines. Parents reported that science activities were fun, focused on learning together and connected to everyday experiences. The use of digital tools complemented the hands-on investigations in powerful ways, for instance by providing opportunities not possible within the class or home and allowing children to easily practice what they learned in hands-on activities. Findings from child assessment data indicated that children in intervention classrooms made significantly more improvement in science learning relative to children in the comparison (business as usual) classrooms and that children who engaged in the home-school connection component made significantly more improvement in science learning relative to children who only participated at school.
